reference.title: Migrating master keys - pkcsep11_migrate utility

titlealts.searchtitle: and : Migrating master keys with pkcsep11_migrate

reference.abstract: There may be situations when the master key on (a domain of) a (CEX*P) must be changed, for example, if company policies require periodic changes of all master keys. Simply changing the master keys using the results in all secure keys stored in the to become useless. Therefore all data encrypted by these keys are lost. To avoid this situation, you must accomplish a master key migration process, where activities on the and on the system must be interlocked. For more information about , read Exploiting Enterprise PKCS #11 using openCryptoki.

keywords.indexterm: master key (MK) migration toolpkcsep11_migrateinstalling, configuring, using

section.p: Per default, the stores all token key objects in the file system in the /var/lib/opencryptoki/ep11tok/TOK_OBJ directory.

All secret and private keys are secure keys, that means they are enciphered (wrapped) with the master key (MK) of the adapter domain. Therefore, the master key is often also referred to as wrapping key. If master keys are changed in a domain of a adapter, all key objects for secure keys in the object repository become invalid. Therefore, all key objects for secure keys must be re-enciphered with the new MK. In order to re-encipher secure keys that are stored as key objects in the object repository, provides the master key migration tool pkcsep11_migrate.

section.title: How to access the master key migration tool
section.p: The pkcsep11_migrate key migration utility is part of versions 3.1 or later, which include the support.

section.title: Prerequisites for the master key migration process
section.p: The master key migration process for the requires a version 7.3 environment. How to set up this environment is described in topic Setting up the TKE environment of Exploiting Enterprise PKCS #11 using openCryptoki.

To use the pkcsep11_migrate migration tool, the crypto stack including must be installed and configured. For information on how to set up this environment, read Exploiting Enterprise PKCS #11 using openCryptoki.

section.title: The master key migration process
section.p: Prerequisite for re-encipherment: The may be configured to use more than one adapter/domain pair to perform its cryptographic operations. This is defined in the configuration file. If the is configured to use more than one adapter/domain pair, then all adapter/domain pairs must be configured to each have the same set of master keys. Therefore, if a master key on one of these adapter/domain pairs is changed, it must be changed on all those other adapter/domain pairs, too.
To migrate master keys on the set of adapter/domain pairs used by an , you must perform the following steps:

ol.li: On the (), submit and commit the same new master key on all adapter/domain combinations used by the .
On , stop all processes that are currently using with the .
On , back up the token object repository of the . For example, you can use the following commands: cd /var/lib/opencryptoki/ep11 tar -cvzf ~/ep11TOK_OBJ_backup.tgz TOK_OBJ

On , migrate the keys of the object repository with the pkcsep11_migrate migration tool (see the invocation information provided at the end of these process steps). The pkcsep11_migrate tool must only be called once for one of the adapter/domain pairs that the uses. If a failure occurs, restore the backed-up token repository and try this step again.Do not continue with step unless step was successful. Otherwise you will lose your encrypted data.
On the , activate the new master keys on all adapter/domain combinations that the uses.
On , restart the applications that used with the .

section.p: In step of the master key migration process, the new master key must be submitted and committed via the TKE interface. That means the new EP11 master key must be in the state Full Committed. The current MK is in the state Valid. Now both (current and new) EP11 master keys are available and accessible. The utility can now decrypt all relevant key objects within the token and re-encrypt all these key objects with the new master key.
section.note: All the decrypt and encrypt operations are done inside the , that means that at no time clear key values are visible within memory.

dlentry.dd: - the card ID; can be retrieved form the card ID in the sysfs (to be retrieved from /sys/devices/ap/cardxx, or with lszcrypt.
- the decimal card domain number (to be retrieved from /sys/bus/ap/ap_domain or with lszcrypt -b)

section.p: All token objects representing secret or private keys that are found for the , are re-encrypted.
section.note: The adapter and domain numbers can be specified in decimal, octal (with prefix 0), or hexadecimal (with prefix 0x) notation. The lszcrypt utility displays these fields in hexadecimal values.
section.p: Usage: You are prompted for your user PIN.

Examples: pkcsep11_migrate -slot 2 -adapter 8 -domain 48 pkcsep11_migrate -slot 0x2 -adapter 010 -domain 0x30 Both invocations migrate the master key for the 8 (octal 010) and domain 48 (hex 0x30) used by the from slot 2.

section.note: The program stops if the re-encryption of a token object fails. In this case, restore the back-up.
section.p: After this utility re-enciphered all key objects, the new master key must be activated. This activation must be done by using the TKE interface command Set, immediate. Finally, the new master key becomes the current master key and the previous master key must be deleted.
section.note: This tool is embedded in the users sbin path and therefore callable from everywhere.
section.p: To prevent token object generation during re-encryption, with the must not be running during re-encryption. It is recommended to make a back-up of the object directory (/usr/local/var/lib/opencryptoki/ep11tok/TOK_OBJ).
